conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light from the light source. The shadow's position and size depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.

When the light source moves closer to the objects, the shadows become larger because the angle at which the light hits the objects increases. Conversely, when the light source moves farther away, the shadows become smaller.

premise: When the light source moves forward (closer) above the objects, the light rays will hit the objects at a more acute angle.
conclusion: This change in angle will cause the shadows to stretch out more in the direction opposite to the light source, making them longer and possibly wider depending on the shape of the objects.
Shadow A is cast by the white object with a curved surface (possibly a bowl or a plate).

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadow will elongate and potentially widen due to the curved surface.
conclusion: Shadow A will elongate and potentially widen.
Shadow B is cast by the rough stone-like object.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadow will also elongate, and its shape might change slightly based on the contours of the stone.
conclusion: Shadow B will elongate and its shape might change slightly.
Shadow C is cast by the red objects (possibly fruits or vegetables).

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadow will similarly elongate and may become more defined if the light source moves closer.
conclusion: Shadow C will elongate and may become more defined.
Shadow D is cast by the book.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadow will elongate along the surface of the ground, maintaining its rectangular shape but becoming longer.
conclusion: Shadow D will elongate and maintain its rectangular shape.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift slightly backward (away from the light source).

When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all elongate and become larger. Additionally, each shadow will shift slightly backward (away from the light source) on the ground.
conclusion: Shadows A, B, C, and D will elongate and become larger, and shift slightly backward.
